ma200:24.1: After he had personally rebuked that monk Ariṣṭa many times, the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
ma200:24.2: “If my explanation of the teaching is entirely and fully understood, you must thus maintain it.
ma200:24.3: If my explanation of the teaching is not entirely and fully understood, then you must ask me and other wise religious practitioners about it.
ma200:24.5: A deluded person might mistakenly understand its meaning and words.
ma200:24.6: As a result of their own mistaken understanding, they’ll know the teaching to be ‘such and such,’ meaning the correct sūtras, songs, assurances, verses, circumstances, records, legends, lectures, birth places, extensive discourses, unprecedented things, and explanations of meaning.
ma200:24.7: They know their meaning in order to debate it; they don’t know their meaning in order to be liberated.
ma200:24.8: Their knowledge of the teaching doesn’t obtain its goal; they only experience suffering and trouble.
ma200:24.10: It’s because they mistakenly understand the teaching.
ma200:25.1: “It’s like a person who wants to catch a snake, so they go searching for one.
ma200:25.2: They walk through a wild forest as they search for a snake.
ma200:25.3: When the person sees a huge snake, they grab it by its tail using their hands.
ma200:25.4: The snake then turns around and raises its head.
ma200:25.5: It might bite their hand, foot, or some other limb.
ma200:26.1: “That person’s attempt to catch a snake doesn’t obtain its goal.
ma200:26.2: They only experience suffering and trouble.
ma200:26.4: It’s because they don’t well understand the way to grasp a snake.
ma200:26.5: Thus, some deluded people mistakenly understand the meaning and the words [of the teaching].
ma200:26.6: As a result of their mistaken understanding, they know the teaching to be ‘such and such,’ meaning the correct sūtras, songs, assurances, verses, circumstances, records, legends, lectures, birth places, extensive discourses, unprecedented things, and explanations of meaning.
ma200:26.7: They know their meaning in order to debate it; they don’t know their meaning in order to be liberated.
ma200:26.8: Their knowledge of the teaching doesn’t obtain its goal; they only experience suffering and trouble.
ma200:26.10: It’s because they mistakenly understand the teaching.
ma200:27.1: “Perhaps there’s a clansman who isn’t mistaken and well understands the meaning and the words [of the teaching].

ma200:27.3: He doesn’t know their meaning in order to debate it; he only knows their meaning in order to be liberated.
ma200:27.4: His knowledge of the teaching obtains its goal, so he doesn’t experience suffering and trouble.

ma200:30.1: “For a long time, I have taught you the parable of the raft because I want you to discard the teaching and don’t not want you to acquire it.
ma200:30.2: How have I taught you the parable of the raft for a long time wanting you to discard the teaching and not wanting you to acquire it?
ma200:31.1: “It’s like a mountain river that’s both deep and wide, and its long current is fast moving.
ma200:31.3: Perhaps someone comes along, and there’s something they want on the other side.
ma200:31.4: When they attempt to cross the river, they think,
ma200:31.5: ‘This mountain river is so deep and wide!
ma200:31.6: Its long current is fast moving, and there’s debris floating in it.
ma200:31.7: There’s no boat or bridge, but I need to cross it.
ma200:31.8: There’s something on the other side that I want to reach.
ma200:31.9: What method will I use to get myself safely to the other side?’
ma200:32.2: ‘Perhaps I could gather a pile of wood and grass on this side, bind it together to make a raft, and then ride it across.’
ma200:33.1: “They then make a pile of wood and grass on the shore, bind it together to fashion a raft, and ride it across, reaching the other side safely.
ma200:33.3: ‘Now, this raft has been quite helpful to me.
ma200:33.4: After riding this raft, I safely made it from that side over to this one.
ma200:33.5: Perhaps I could put it over my right shoulder or carry it on my head when I leave.’
ma200:34.1: “They then put the raft on their right shoulder or carry it on their head.
ma200:34.2: What do you think about that plan?
ma200:34.3: Will this raft be of help to them?”
ma200:36.2: “How would he get more help from this raft?
ma200:36.4: ‘This raft of mine was quite helpful.
ma200:36.5: After riding this raft, I safely made it from that side over to this one.
ma200:36.6: Perhaps I could put this raft back in the water, or perhaps I could put it on the shore and leave it there.’
ma200:37.1: “That man then puts his raft back in the water or puts it on the shore and leaves it.
ma200:37.3: By doing this, will he get any help from this raft?”
ma200:39.2: “Thus, for a long time, I’ve taught you the parable of the raft wanting you to discard the teaching and not wanting you to acquire it.
ma200:39.3: If you know that I’ve taught you the parable of the raft for a long time, you will abandon this teaching, so why wouldn’t you abandon what’s not the teaching?

ma200:76.1: “He is known as a monk who has crossed the moat, gone beyond the moat, has breached the city wall, has no gate, and is a mirror of noble wisdom.
ma200:76.2: How has the monk crossed the moat?
ma200:76.3: He has exhausted the moat of ignorance and has known it.
ma200:76.4: He uprooted it completely and broke through to no more future birth.
ma200:76.5: Thus, the monk has crossed the moat.
ma200:77.1: “How has the monk gone beyond the moat?
ma200:77.2: He has ended craving for existence and has known it.
ma200:77.3: He uprooted it completely and broke through to no more future birth.
ma200:77.4: Thus, the monk has gone beyond the moat.
ma200:78.1: “How has the monk breached the city wall?
ma200:78.2: He has ended endless birth and death and has known it.
ma200:78.3: He uprooted it completely and broke through to no more future birth.
ma200:78.4: Thus, the monk has broken through the city wall.
ma200:79.1: “How does the monk have no gate?
ma200:79.2: He has ended the five lower bonds and has known it.
ma200:79.3: He has uprooted them completely and broken through to no more future birth.

ma200:83.2: If another person respects the Tathāgata and offers support, serves, and venerates him, what does the Tathāgata think?
ma200:83.4: ‘Is there something I know and have ended now that causes this to take place?’
ma200:83.5: That’s what the Tathāgata thinks when another person respects the Tathāgata and offers support, serves, and venerates him.”
ma200:84.2: “If another person ridicules you and assaults you with numerous hateful insults or if they are respectful, offer support, serve, and venerate you, don’t make this a cause to be hateful and resentful; don’t become harmful.
ma200:84.3: Don’t be encouraged or joyous, and don’t be happy at heart.
ma200:84.5: We have no soul, and nothing is possessed by a soul.
ma200:85.1: “It’s like the dry grass and withered wood outside the entrance of this Jeta’s Grove.
ma200:85.2: Perhaps another person takes it way, burns it, or makes use of it as they like.
ma200:85.4: Does that dry grass and withered wood think this:
ma200:85.5: ‘That person took us away, burned us, and made use of us as they liked’?”
ma200:87.1: “Thus, if another person ridicules you and assaults you with numerous hateful insults, or if they are respectful, offer support, serve, and venerate you, this too should cause you not to be hateful or resentful.
ma200:87.3: Don’t be encouraged or joyous, either.
ma200:87.6: We have no soul, and nothing is possessed by a soul.
ma200:88.1: “My teaching is well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as it’s proclaimed, even up to the heavens.
ma200:88.2: Thus is my teaching well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as its proclaimed, even up to the heavens:
ma200:88.3: If someone of correct wisdom is liberated, then they don’t claim there’s something that doesn’t end when their life ends.
ma200:89.1: “My teaching is well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as it’s proclaimed, even up to the heavens.
ma200:89.2: Thus is my teaching well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as its proclaimed, even up to the heavens:
ma200:89.3: If someone has ended the five lower bonds, then at the end of their life they’ll be born elsewhere and [attain] parinirvāṇa.
ma200:89.4: Attaining irreversibility, they won’t return to this world.
ma200:90.1: “My teaching is well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as it’s proclaimed, even up to the heavens.
ma200:90.2: Thus is my teaching well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as its proclaimed, even up to the heavens:
ma200:90.3: If someone has ended the three bonds and lust, anger, and delusion are weakened, they’ll be reborn once more up in heaven or among men.
ma200:90.4: After that one rebirth, then they’ll reach the limit of suffering.
ma200:91.1: “My teaching is well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as it’s proclaimed, even up to the heavens.
ma200:91.2: Thus is my teaching well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as its proclaimed, even up to the heavens:
ma200:91.3: If someone has ended the three bonds and attained stream entry, they won’t fall into bad states.
ma200:91.4: They are certainly headed for correct awakening, being reborn up in heaven or among humans not more than seven times.
ma200:91.5: After seven rebirths, then they’ll reach the limit of suffering.
ma200:92.1: “My teaching is well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as it’s proclaimed, even up to the heavens.
ma200:92.2: Thus is my teaching well expressed, revealed, and disseminated, has nothing pointless, and spreads as its proclaimed, even up to the heavens:
ma200:92.3: If someone is faithful and happy with me, then at the end of their life they’ll be born in a good place like the others, with a remainder.”
ma200:93.2: Those monks who heard what the Buddha taught rejoiced and approved.
